The design principle conceptualised in G4 suggests the use of gestures resembling actions performed in a real-world context.

rule_name: Prevention of Accidental Critical Commands through Voluntary Actions
description: Secondary tasks comprise the ones devoted to minimising the chances of accidentally issuing driving commands, by enabling and disabling them in accordance with the functional state of the vehicle and forcing the driver to perform voluntary actions to move from one state to another.

rule_name: Mimicry of Real-World Action for 'Move' State Transition
description: This gesture mimics the action of releasing the handbrake, i.e., the secondary command enabling the primary driving commands.

rule_name: Mimicry of Real-World Action for 'Stop' State Transition
description: This gesture mimics the action of pressing the start/stop button of a car, i.e., the secondary command which turns off the engine.

rule_name: Proprioceptive and Visual Feedback for 'Move' Gesture Learnability
description: In our case, the user learns the association between the action and its effects in terms of proprioception and delayed visual feed-back, since a correct execution of the gesture makes the robot move in response to a continuous gesture.

rule_name: Proprioceptive and Visual Feedback for 'Stop' Gesture Learnability
description: The association between the action and its effects is given in terms of proprioception and visual feedback, i.e., a correct execution of the gesture makes the robot stop.

rule_name: Minimize Overall Response Time for Usability
description: Minimising the overall response time of a human-robot interaction interface is a key enabling factor for its usability.

rule_name: Bound Recognition Module Delay for User Experience
description: Although the delay δr introduced by the recognition module does not affect the moving state, as described in (5), it is convenient to keep it bounded to enhance user’s experience.
An interface's gestures should be natural and comfortable to use.

rule_name: Ease of Use of the System
description: The system should be easy to use.
